page.title: 01CHESTER-LE-STREET
page.content: The market town of Chester-le-Street is situated in the North East of England in County Durham,about eight miles south of Newcastle and seven miles north of the cathedral city of Durham. Chester-le-Street itself lies on the western side of the river Wear.In Roman times it was called 'Congcangium' and was an important Roman camp.In A.D. 883 Lindisfarne monks brought St. Cuthbert's body to Chester-le-Street while searching for a safe burial place.They stayed at St. Cuthbert's church, which now has a spire of 169 feet.Chester-le-Street has an excellent line of communication ,being on the East Coast main line railway,linking London and Edinburgh. This runs over an impressive 11 span viaduct.
